abstract_summ: In this paper, we gathered case data from Jan 22, 2020 to April 14 for 6 countries to compare different models' proficiency in COVID-19 cases prediction.We assessed the performance of 3 machine learning models including hidden Markov chain model (HMM), hierarchical Bayes model, and long-short-term-memory model (LSTM) using the root-mean-square error (RMSE).The estimated end of the pandemics (with 97 percent of cases reaching an outcome) starts as of May 28th for some states and rests through August 14th, 2020.In this paper, we propose a machine learning technics and SIR models (deterministic and stochastic cases) with numerical approximations to predict the number of cases infected with the COVID-19, for both in few days and the following three weeks.The LSTM model had the consistently smallest prediction error rates for tracking the dynamics of incidents cases in 4 countries.Besides providing basic projections for confirmed and fatality cases, the proposed SuEIR model is also able to predict the peak date of active cases, and estimate the basic reproduction number (R0).
title_summ: Guided Machine Learning for COVID-19 Forecasts in the United StatesPredictive Analysis of COVID-19 Time-series Data from Johns Hopkins UniversityForecasting Covid-19 dynamics in Brazil: a data driven approachComparative prediction of confirmed cases with COVID-19 pandemic by machine learning, deterministic and stochastic SIR modelsForecasting the Spread of Covid-19 Under Control Scenarios Using LSTM and Dynamic Behavioral ModelsForecasting COVID-19 cases using Machine Learning modelsForecasting Covid-19 dynamics in Brazil: a data driven approachEpidemic Model
title_abstract_phrases: The estimated end of the pandemics (with 97 percent of cases reaching an outcome) starts as of May 28th for some states and rests through August 14th, 2020.Comparative prediction of confirmed cases with COVID-19 pandemic by machine learning, deterministic and stochastic SIR modelsIn this paper, we propose a machine learning technics and SIR models (deterministic and stochastic cases) with numerical approximations to predict the number of cases infected with the COVID-19, for both in few days and the following three weeks.In this paper, we gathered case data from Jan 22, 2020 to April 14 for 6 countries to compare different models' proficiency in COVID-19 cases prediction.The prediction results for all states in the US can be found on our project website: https://covid19.uclaml.org, which are updated on a weekly basis, and have been adopted by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) for COVID-19 death forecasts (https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/covid-data/forecasting-us.html).Predictive Analysis of COVID-19 Time-series Data from Johns Hopkins UniversityWe provide a predictive analysis of the spread of COVID-19, also known as SARS-CoV-2, using the dataset made publicly available online by the Johns Hopkins University.We assessed the performance of 3 machine learning models including hidden Markov chain model (HMM), hierarchical Bayes model, and long-short-term-memory model (LSTM) using the root-mean-square error (RMSE).Specifically, the SuEIR model is a variant of the SEIR model by taking into account the untested/unreported cases of COVID-19, and trained by machine learning algorithms based on the reported historical data.
